name: Amber Dry Extract
notes: Amber colored dry malt extract, for general purpose use. Use in any medium to dark colored beer. Examples: Ales, Marzens, Amber Ale, India Pale Ale

name: Amber Liquid Extract
notes: Unhopped amber color liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any Ale. Examples: Amber ale, India Pale Ale, Munich style, Marzen, Bock

name: Barley Hulls
notes: Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.

name: Barley, Torrefied
notes: Raw barley that has been "popped" open to open kernels Used in place of raw barley for faster conversion and higher yields. High in haze producing protein

name: Black (Patent) Malt
notes: Dark color and dry roasted flavor characteristic of Stouts and Porters Use for: Coloring in small amounts, or flavoring of Stouts and Porters in larger amounts.

name: Black Barley (Stout)
notes: Unmalted barley roasted at high temperature to create a dry, coffee like flavor. Imparts a sharp acrid flavor characteristic of dry stouts. Gives "dryness" to a stout or porter -- much more so than regular Roasted Barley

name: Brown Sugar, Dark
notes: Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.

name: Brown Sugar, Light
notes: Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.

name: Candi Sugar, Amber
notes: Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer.  Darker variants also add color.

name: Candi Sugar, Clear
notes: Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer.  Darker variants also add color.

name: Candi Sugar, Dark
notes: Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer.  Darker variants also add color.

name: Cane (Beet) Sugar
notes: Common household baking sugar. Lightens flavor and body of beer. Can contribute a cider-like flavor to the beer if not cold-fermented or used in large quantities.

name: Cara-Pils/Dextrine
notes: Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Foam"

name: Caraamber
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

name: Caraaroma
notes: Very dark crystal malt - similar to a crystal 120 or Caramunich 120 malt.  Adds strong caramel flavor, red color, and malty aroma.

name: Carafa I
notes: Used to intensify aroma and color in dark, Munich beers and stouts.

name: Carafa II
notes: Used to intensify aroma and color in dark, Munich beers and stouts.

name: Carafa III
notes: Dark color and aroma - used in some German beers

name: Carafoam
notes: Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Pils (TM)"

name: Caramel Wheat Malt
notes: Caramel wheat malt - emphasizes wheat malt aroma and adds color to the beer.  Popular for Dunkelweizens.  Also known as Carawheat -- which is a registered trademark of Wyermann Malting.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 10L
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 20L
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 30L
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 40L
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 60L
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 80L
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt -120L
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.  Very Dark

name: Caramunich Malt
notes: Caramel, copper colored malt.  Used in Belgian ales and German bocks.

name: Carared
notes: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

name: Caravienne Malt
notes: Light Belgian crystal malt.  Used in light Trappist and Abbey style Belgian ales.

name: Chocolate Malt
notes: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

name: Chocolate Malt
notes: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

name: Chocolate Rye Malt
notes: Primarily used for color and aroma in top-fermented specialty beers.

name: Chocolate Wheat Malt
notes: Intensifies aroma and color in top-fermented beers such as dark wheat beers.

name: Corn Sugar (Dextrose)
notes: Widely used for bottling at rate of approx 2/3 cup per 5 gallons of beer

name: Corn Syrup
notes: Syrup derived from corn with many of the same properties as corn sugar.  May be used to enhance gravity without adding much body or flavor.  Limit percentage in batch to avoid wine/cider flavors.

name: Dark Dry Extract
notes: Dark dry extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any dark ale or lager.

name: Dark Liquid Extract
notes: Unhopped dark liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any dark beer. Examples: Porter, Brown ale, Bock, Oktoberfest, Stouts

name: Dememera Sugar
notes: Dark, unrefined brown sugar that contains molasses and other dark impurities.  Great for brown ales and porters.  Adds slight sweetness and smooth character.

name: Extra Light Dry Extract
notes: Very light color dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any ale or lager.

name: Grits
notes: Imparts a corn or grain taste.  Mash required. Used to increase gravity of American lagers.

name: Honey - Apple Blossom
notes: Light to medium amber in color and a hint of apple in the aroma.

name: Invert Sugar
notes: Used to increase starting gravity and also as an adjunct for some Belgian and English ales.

name: Light Dry Extract
notes: Pale dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any full bodied ale or lager.

name: Lyle's Golden Syrup
notes: Liquid Invert Sugar.  Used to increase alcohol and lighten the beer without alterning flavor.  Used in Belgian ales and some English ales.

name: Maple Syrup
notes: If added during the boil it will add a dry, woodsy flavor. If added at bottling, the smooth maple flavor comes through.  Used for maple ales, porters, browns.

name: Milk Sugar (Lactose)
notes: Not fermentable, so it adds lasting sweetness. Lactose can be added to lend  sweetness to Sweet Stouts and Porters.

name: Molasses
notes: Imparts a strong, sweet flavor.  Used primarily in stouts and porters.

name: Pale Liquid Extract
notes: Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.

name: Peat Smoked Malt
notes: Robust smoky malt that provides a smoky flavor.  Used in scottish ales and wee heavy ales.

name: Pilsner Liquid Extract
notes: Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.

name: Rice Extract Syrup
notes: Used like other rice adjuncts in American and Japenes lagers to provide a dry, clean taste and light body.  Adds gravity without changing body or flavor substantially.  Use in place of corn sugar in small quantities.

name: Rice Hulls
notes: Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes. It is recommended that 10-15% of the total grain bill weight be made up of rice hulls. This includes the weight of the hulls on rice malts that have their hulls intact. By weight, rice malts with hulls are 37.5% hull and 62.5% seed. Calculate the total weight of your grain bill and then calculate the total weight of the rice hulls already included to see if the total weight of the included rice hulls is already 10-15% of your grain bill weight. Add more rice hulls if necessary.

name: Roasted Barley
notes: Roasted at high temperature to create a burnt, grainy, coffee like flavor. Imparts a red to deep brown color to beer, and very strong roasted flavor. Use 2-4% in Brown ales to add a nutty flavor, or 3-10% in Porters and Stouts for coffee flavor.

name: Rye Malt
notes: Adds a dry, crisp character to the beer. Yields a deep red color, and a distinctive rye flavor Must limit to 10-15% fo the mash as it tends to produce "stuck" mashes.

name: Rye, Flaked
notes: Imparts a dry, crisp rye flavor to rye beers.  Can be easier to mash than raw rye.

name: Smoked Malt
notes: Malt that has been smoked over an open fire. Creates a distinctive "smoked" flavor and aroma. Used primarily for German Rauchbier but can also be added to Brown Ales and Porters.

name: Special B Malt
notes: Extreme caramel aroma and flavored malt.  Used in dark Belgian Abbey and Trappist ales.  Unique flavor and aroma.

name: Sugar, Table (Sucrose)
notes: White table sugar, or sucrose primarily is used to increase alcohol. Using too much will add a cider flavor to beer.

name: Treacle
notes: UK mixture of molasses, invert sugar and golden (corn) syrup.  Imparts an intense sweet flavor and dark color.  Used in dark English ales.  Also called "Black Treacle" or the brand name "Lyle's Black Treacle Syrup."

name: Turbinado
notes: Light, raw brown sugar.  May be used in British pale ales or high gravity Belgian ales.  Limit percentage used to avoid undesirable flavors.  Similar to Demerara sugar.

name: Wheat Dry Extract
notes: Wheat based dry extract for use in all wheat beers. Use as base or to increase gravity of any wheat beer. Examples: Weizen, weiss, wheat ales and lagers

name: Wheat Liquid Extract
notes: Unhopped Wheat liquid malt extract. Contains approx 60% Wheat, 40% Barley Use for Bavarian wheats, weizens, weiss and dunkel weizen styles.

name: Munich Malt
notes: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a reddish amber color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

name: Munich Malt - 10L
notes: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a slight orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

name: Munich Malt - 20L
notes: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a orange to deep orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

name: Barley, Flaked
notes: Adds significant body to Porters and Stouts.  High haze producing protein prevents use in light beers.

name: Barley, Raw
notes: Raw, unmalted barley can be used to add body to your beer.  Use in homebrew requires very fine milling combined with a decoction or multi-stage mash.  Performs best when used in small quantities with well modified grains.

name: Oats, Flaked
notes: Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer Used in oatmeal stouts and porters Adds substantial protein haze to light beers Protein rest recommended unless flakes are pregelatinized

name: Oats, Malted
notes: Malted oats.  Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer  Creates chill haze in lighter beers, so is primarily used in dark ones.

name: Amber Malt
notes: Roasted specialty malt used in some English browns, milds and old ales to add color and a biscuit taste.  Intense flavor - so limit use. Low diastatic power so must be mashed with well modified malts.

name: Biscuit Malt
notes: Use for English ales, brown ales and porters. Adds a biscuit like flavor and aroma. Can be used as a substitute for toasted malt.

name: Brumalt
notes: Dark German malt developed to add malt flavor of Alt, Marzen and Oktoberfest beers. Helps create authentic maltiness without having to do a decoction mash.  Rarely available for homebrewers.

name: Honey Malt
notes: Intensely sweet - adds a sweet malty flavor sometimes associated with honey.  Also called Brumalt.

name: Melanoiden Malt
notes: Aromatic malt from Banberg, Germany.  Promotes a full flavor and rounds off beer color. Promotes deep red color and malty flavor.

name: Toasted Malt
notes: Toasted malt can be made at home by toasting pale malted barley for 10-15 minutes at 350 F.  Similar to Biscuit or Victory malt - this malt adds reddish/orange color and improved body without sweetness.  Toasted flavor.  Mashing required to avoid haze.

name: Victory Malt
notes: Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales. Use for: Nut brown ales, porters

name: Brown Malt
notes: Imparts a dry, biscuit flavor. Used in nut brown ales, porters and some Belgian ales.

name: Special Roast
notes: Use for English ales, nut brown ales and porters. Adds a toasted, biscuit like flavor and aroma

name: Aromatic Malt
notes: Provides a very strong malt flavor and aroma to your beer.

name: Acid Malt
notes: Acid malt contains acids from natural lactic acids.  Used by German brewers to adjust malt PH without chemicals to adhere to German purity laws.  Also enhances the head retention.

name: Mild Malt
notes: Also called "English Mild" - a light specialty malt used in Brown Ales

name: Pale Malt (2 Row) Bel
notes: Base malt for all beer styles Higher potential yield than US, English equivalent pale ale malts

name: Pale Malt (2 Row) UK
notes: Base malt for all English beer styles Lower diastatic power than American 2 Row Pale Malt

name: Pale Malt (2 Row) US
notes: Base malt for all beer styles

name: Pale Malt (6 Row) US
notes: Base malt for all beer styles

name: Pale Malt, Maris Otter
notes: Premium base malt from the UK.  Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.

name: Vienna Malt
notes: Kiln dried malt darker than Pale Malt, but not as dark as Munich Malt Imparts a golden to orange color to the beer.

name: Lager Malt
notes: Very light lager malt used to make Pilsners, Lagers and other light beers.  May be used as a base malt.

name: Pilsner (2 Row) Bel
notes: Belgian base malt for Continental lagers

name: Pilsner (2 Row) Ger
notes: German base for Pilsners and Bohemian Lagers

name: Pilsner (2 Row) UK
notes: Pilsner base malt

name: Rice, Flaked
notes: Used to add fermentables without increasing body or flavor. Produces a milder, less grainy tasting beer. Examples: American lagers, Bohemian lagers, Pilsners

name: Corn, Flaked
notes: Generally a neutral flavor, used to reduce maltiness of beer Produces beer with a milder, less malty flavor Uses: Primarily for light Bohemian and Pilsner lagers

name: Wheat Malt, Bel
notes: Malted wheat for use in Wheat beers

name: Wheat Malt, Dark
notes: Dark malted wheat base for use in dark wheat styles such as Dunkleweizen.

name: Wheat Malt, Ger
notes: Malted wheat base for use in all wheat styles

name: Wheat, Flaked
notes: Flaked wheat adds to increased body and foam retention Used in place of raw or torrified wheat for faster conversion and better yield. May be used in small amounts to improve head retention and body Examples: Belgian White beer, Wit

name: Wheat, Roasted
notes: Also called Chocolate Wheat Malt.  Kilned raw wheat - adds a deep, dark brown color to dunkelweizens and other dark beer styles. Roasted, woody, charcoal or burnt toast flavor depending on degree of roasting.

name: Wheat, Torrified
notes: Unmodified wheat that has been "popped" to open the kernels Used primarily in place of raw wheat when making Belgian White and Wit Faster conversion and higher yield than raw wheat Protein rest recommended when mashing

name: White Wheat Malt
notes: White wheat gives a malty flavor not available from raw wheat. Used in Weiss, Wit and White beers

name: Maltodextrin
notes: Used to add mouthfeel to a beer.  It is marked as non-fermentable as it is usually 97% unfermentable sugars.

name: Black Currant Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Just Black Currant' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Cranberry Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Just Cranberry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Blueberry Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Just Blueberry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Black Cherry Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Just Black Cherry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation.  SRM color listed is a rough estimate. Note - their tart cherry has more tannins and will produce more flavor post-fermentation.

name: Organic Cranberry Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Organic Just Cranberry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Tart Cherry Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Just Tart Cherry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

notes: Knudsen's 'Just Pomegranate' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Organic Concord Grape Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Organic Just Concord Grape' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Organic Pomegranate Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Organic Just Pomegranate' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Organic Tart Cherry Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Organic Just Tart Cherry' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Organic Prune Juice - Knudsen
notes: Knudsen's 'Organic Just Prune' juice suitable for use in mead, wine, cider, beer.  Sold in 1 quart jars.  Pasteurized but has no preservatives making it suitable for fermentation. SRM color listed is a rough estimate.

name: Honey
notes: Generic honey - usually Clover honey is sold in US supermarkets.  Will generally lighten body and flavor when used in beer as it is highly fermentable.  Modern methods add honey directly to the primary to avoid boiling away aroma and flavor.  Some varieties have additional flavors (see the Honey Varietals add-on).

name: Honey - Buckwheat
notes: Probably the strongest and darkets of varietal honey. Dark in color. Strong molasses finish and capable of making "single malt" meads.  Can be musty and earthy in aroma. Some eastern varieties can take on a "barnyard" character though western US versions are less so. The strong flavor can overwhelm/conflict with many fruits and spices, so select complementatry flavor combos.

name: Honey - Avacado
notes: A flavorful, earthy honey made by bees foraging on avacado trees.  Dark amber color. Hints of molasses and sorghum, a rich, full bodied flavorful honey.

name: Honey - Cranberry
notes: Mild and fruity in flavor with a tart aftertaste.  Medium amber color.

name: Honey - Wildflower
notes: Wildflower bees capture nectars from a wide variety of trees, shrubs, and flowers.  Some variability due to wide range of production.  Deep, rich, and not as sweet as clover honey.  Some examples really capture wild character of flora used. Quite a bit of variability in production - so sample before using.

name: Honey - Eucalyptus
notes: A rich distinctive honey made from bees foraging Eucalyptus trees in Australia. A full body honey with hints of Eucalyptus.

name: Honey - Heather
notes: Slightly bitter with an aftertaste of burnt caramel.  Dark amber in color.

name: Honey - Orange Blossom
notes: Orange blossom honey is a favorite of fruit mead makers.  A delicate fragrance, sweet and clean fermenting.  Fragrant, light, heady, slight hints of orange blossom.

name: Honey - Mesquite
notes: Light, delicate and hints of mesquite flavor, but not smoky.  Makes a nice single variety mead if you enjoy the flavor of the honey.

name: Honey - Raspberry
notes: Raspberry honey from the white blossoms of the raspberry bush.  Amber in color, mellow finish and hints of raspberry.  Slightly fruity and pairs well with vanilla.

name: Honey - Pumpkin Blossom
notes: Made once a year from the nectar of Pumpkin Blossoms in early fall.  Dark, amber colored with a light floral fragrance.  Works well when contrasted with spicy foods and spices.  It does not taste like pumpkin pie, however.

name: Honey - Blueberry
notes: Deep flavor profile from bees foraging on blueberry bushes.  Mid color range with a slightly fruity character.

name: Honey - Tupelo
notes: The champagne of honey.  Highly prized by many mead makers. Tupelo honey is light amber with a slightly greenish color and a pear-like hoppy aroma. Delicate, mild, buttery, floral.  Works well with many fruits.

name: Honey - Blackberry
notes: Medium light in color and very sweet.  Some fruity character comes thorugh from the blackberries.

name: Honey - Fireweed
notes: Fireweed comes from a perennial herb grown in the Pacific North West US.  Sweet, complex, buttery taste.  Buttery finish.

name: Honey - Chesnut
notes: Produced primarily in Italy from the blossoms of chesnut trees.  Has a unique aroma and slightly bitter flavor.  Amber in color, and only mildly sweet.

name: Honey - Sourwood
notes: Sourwood honey is sweet, light colored and dlicate.  It has a caramel or buttery flavor to it and a pleasant buttery aftertaste.

name: Honey - Sage
notes: Sage honey is made primarily in California.  It is heavy bodied but has a mild flavor.  It is often blended with other honeys as it does not easily granulate.

name: Honey - Acacia
notes: Acacia honey is made from the nectar of black locust plants.  Very sweet with a mild delicate floral taste.  High fructose content, often used therapeutically.

name: Honey - Alfalfa
notes: Alfalfa is a light, delicate honey made from bees feeding on alfalfa.  In meads is delicate and fairly clean in flavor.

name: Honey - Basswood
notes: Made from Basswood blossoms in North America. One of the few light colored honeys that has a strong biting flavor.  Woody scents and a strong biting flavor.

name: Honey - Clover
notes: The most common variety sold in supermarkets with a huge annual production.  Delicate and relatively neutral in flavor.  Some variation due to the large production area.

name: Honey - Sunflower
notes: Distinctive floral aromas.  Easily crystalizes.  Light to medium amber in color.

name: Apple Juice - Blenheim Orange
notes: For cider - low in aroma, tart, highly acidic with some astringency.  Somewhat tart on its own but may be a good apple for a blend.  Total tannins = 0.12%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/blenheim-orange

name: Apple Juice - Black Gilliflower
notes: Cider making variety.  Medium to medium large. Full bodied, balanced, sharp cider apple with a pleasant bite.  Notable but mild tannins, some woody notes. Wine like.  Total tannins=0.14% For more info see: https://brixcider.com/black-gilliflower-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Christmas Pearmain
notes: For cider - Medium to light body.  Moderate to slightly high acidity with a long finish.  Little in the way of tannins.  Good cider base, straightforward.  Total tannins=0.11%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/christmas-pearmain-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Cortland
notes: Popular eating apple bred in NY in the late 1800s.  For cider -Low to medium body.  Moderate acidity - starts mild then builds and fades slowly.  Little to no noticeable tannins.  Mild sour apple flavor.  Not an exciting cider, but may work well in a blend. Total tannins=0.06%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/cortland-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice  - Early Windsor
notes: Known as Alkmene in Germany where it was initially grown.  For cider - Medium to light body.  Medium to high acidity.  Long tart finish.  Slightly drying but otherwise no noticeable tannins..  Total tannins=0.11%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/earlywindsor

name: Apple Juice - Coopers Market
notes: For cider -Medium body.  Dominated by tart, lingering green apple acidity, somewhat biting but not overly harsh.  Little noticeable tannins.  Total tannins=0.07%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/coopers-market-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Egremont Russet
notes: For cider - Medium body, noticeable alcohol.  Moderate to high acidity, like tart cherry juice.  Long finish.  Little noticeable tannins. Total tannins=0.12%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/egremont-russet-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Gala
notes: Popular Eating Apple.  For cider - Straight forward cider flavor.  Medium body.  Medium to low acidity.  Little to no tannins.  Simple.  Clean, very easy to drink.  Nothing exciting but not bad. Total tannins=0.05%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/gala-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Garfield
notes: An apple grafted from a tree at the Garfield Farm Museum in LaFox, Illinois. Excellent cider.  Nicely balanced.  Intriguing aroma and full flavor.  Intriguing story to the apple as well.Total tannins=0.16%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/garfield

name: Apple Juice - Gloster
notes: For cider - Initial burst of flavor and gushing, juicy mouthfeel that fades to a lingering astringency.  Moderate acidity and notable "bite" of alcohol.  The astringent finish suggests more tannins than testing revealed. Good, full flavored cider with nice balance of acids.  It stands up fairly well on its own or could be used to add some oomph to a weaker cider. Total tannins=0.12%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/gloster-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Grimes Golden
notes: Heirloom apple.  For cider - Green apple skin.  Even tart flavor from start to finish.  Mild bitterness and astringency. Distinctly "green apple" cider.  Refreshing, balanced.  Very good on its own.  Total tannins=0.12%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/grimes-golden-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Haralson
notes: Slightly tart apple from Minnesota.  For cider - Light to medium body.  Medium to slightly high acidity.  A hint of something funky  - perhaps something wasn't perfectly clean and happy during the fermentation (we don't claim to be perfect).  Little to no noticeable tannins. Probably could have been better (blame the cider maker).  Even so, it was a little thin.  Could be used to add some acidity to a blend. Total tannins=0.10%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/haralson-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Carrol
notes: For cider - medium to light in body, medium acidity, a mild tart apple.  Slightly more astringent than low tannin would expect.  Total tannins=0.08%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/carroll

name: Apple Juice - Hauer Pippin
notes: For cider -Mellow, straight-forward apple flavor.  Unassuming on first sip but a long, lingering finish.  Moderate acidity.  Little to no noticeable tannins. Light, subtle, and drinkable.  Unadorned apple flavor and aroma.  Would make a fine backdrop for blending with almost any apple. Total tannins=0.08%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/hauer-pippin-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Horneburger Pancake
notes: From Northern Germany.  For cider - Medium body.  Medium to high acidity.  Subtle but noticeable bitterness.  Little astringency.  Long, tart finish. Makes a pretty good cider, would add some acidity, unique aroma, and subtle bitterness to a blend.Total tannins=0.13%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/horneburger-pancake

name: Apple Juice - Honeycrisp
notes: Popular eating variety.  For cider - Medium to light body.  Moderate acidity.  Little to no noticeable tannins. Nothing exciting but not bad.  Would make a good, neutral base for blending with other apples. Mild apple flavor. Total tannins=0.07%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/honeycrisp-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Lady Sweet
notes: Mild flavor.  For cider - Low acidity.  Light mouthfeel.  Mild apple skin flavor.  Little to no noticeable tannins.  Mild cider overall.  Nothing remarkable but nothing bad.  Easy to drink.  Could mellow an overly sharp cider. Total tannins=0.07%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/lady-sweet

name: Apple Juice - London Pippen
notes: Crisp with a pleasant apple flavor but not very juicy.  For cider - Fresh apple flavor.  Refreshing and balanced.  Medium body, medium acidity, little to no tannin. Overall Impression – Enjoyable cider.  Classic apple flavor. Total tannins=0.07%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/london-pippen-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Marin Oufroy
notes: French Cider Apple.  For cider - Full mouthfeel.  Sherry-like.  Noticeable sweetness with the low acidity.  Soft tannins.  Woody.  Baked apple, raisin.  Alcohol finish. Overall Impression - Excellent cider.  Rich, complex.  Highly recommended. Total tannins=0.31%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/marin-oufroy-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Perry Russet
notes: Seeling apple from Iola Wisconson.  For cider -  Medium body.  High acidity dominates the flavor, like “biting into a lemon” though there is nothing particularly citric about it.  Long, tart, dry finish.  No noticeable bitterness but some astringency. Overall Impression – A good cider apple overall.  Probably too tart on its own for most palettes, but the acidity and moderate astringency would lend well to a blend. Total tannins=0.19%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/perry-russet

name: Apple Juice - Macintosh
notes: Popular eating apple.  For cider - Medium body.  Fresh, tart apple flavor.  Moderate to strong acidity. Overall Impression – This common eating apple makes a pleasant cider with the familiar tart apple flavor of a Mac.  Great base apple.  Could make for a world class cider if blended with a bittersweet.  Total tannins=0.11%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/macintosh-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Minkler
notes: Heirloom apple from the 1800s.  For cider - Moderate mouthfeel.  Little acidity.  Noticeable tannins, mildly bitter and astringent.  Slightly woody, leathery flavor. Overall Impression – A unique cider both in terms of the story of the apple and its uncommon flavor.  Could be bumped up with a higher gravity, higher acidity apple, but interesting on its own.Total tannins=0.16%. For more info see: https://brixcider.com/minkler-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Northwestern Greening
notes: Seeling apple from Iola Wisconson.  For cider - Medium body leaning towards light.  Nice acidity - not too strong, not too weak.  Easy to drink, green apple flavor with a note of pine.  Little to no noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - Exceptionally drinkable cider.  Light and refreshing. Total tannins=0.09%. https://brixcider.com/northwest-greening-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Shiawassee
notes: For cider - Moderate, soft mouthfeel that gives way to full and long lasting acidity.  Little noticeable tannins. Overall Impression – Great for adding aromatics and acidity to a blend, a little too acidic on its own. Total tannins=0.10%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/shiawassee

name: Apple Juice - Pitmaston Pineapple
notes: Old English heiloom.  For cider - Medium body.  Impressively tart.  Like pineapple juice without any sugar.  Brisk, full flavor.  Long, tart finish.  Little noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - A distinctive cider.  Too acidic on its own for some palettes.  Would liven up a blend with some tropical tang. Total tannins=0.10%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/pitmaston-pineapple-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Plumb Cider
notes: Origin unknown, pleasant and juicy.  For cider - Medium body.  Medium to high acidity.  Lightly drying and mildly bitter.  Long, dry finish with lingering acidity and bitterness. Overall Impression - Very good cider on its own.  Nice balance of acidity and tannins. Total tannins=0.15%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/plumb-cider

name: Apple Juice - Raven
notes: Rich dark plum colored apple from Washington state  For cider - Medium body.  Very tart, like cranberry juice.  Long finish.  Little to no noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - Great apple for bumping up the acidity of a blend.  Full tart flavor. Total tannins=0.09%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/raven

name: Apple Juice - Razor Russet
notes: Similar to Golden Delicious. For cider - Medium body.  Alcohol bite fills it out.  Nice acidity level - not too high, not too low.  Little to no noticeable tannins.  Pleasant apple/grape flavor. Overall Impression - A very good cider on its own.  It's attractive, and everything is in nice balance (except that it lacks tannins). Total tannins=0.08%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/razor-russet-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Red Cortland
notes: Large, very similar to a regular Cortland, just a bit redder.  For cider - Low to medium body.  Light at first with a tart, lingering finish.  Medium acidity overall.  Little to no noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - Very drinkable cider.  Fine for a base apple.  Might be nice to have a higher gravity apple to fill it out, but it's nonetheless enjoyable as a light, refreshing cider. Total tannins=0.06%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/red-cortland-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Russet Cow
notes: Crunchy medium size apple.  For cider - Medium body.  High acidity.  Long, tart finish.  Little to no noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - Perhaps too one dimensional to stand on its own but could be used to add acidity to a blend. Total tannins=0.06%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/russet-cow

name: Apple Juice - Snow
notes: Variable sized apple also known as Fameuse.  Bi-color green and red.  Originated from plantings by French settlers in Quebec. For cider - Soft mouthfeel and a bit thin.  Mildly tart with some lingering acidity.  Little to no noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - A light, refreshing cider.  A good cider base with balanced acidity that would blend well with a bittersweet.Total tannins=0.06%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/snow-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Wisconsin Russet
notes: Also known as Jeidy Russet.  For cider - Full body.  High acidity.  Rich, puckery fruit flavors.  Long, mouth-watering finish.  Mild bitterness and astringency rounds out the cider. Overall Impression -  Very good cider.  From it's cold Wisconsin home, this apple produces a surprising, tart fruit punch that brings memories of warmer weather and can carry one away to a bright, tropical place even on a wintry night. Total tannins=0.25%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/wisconsin-russet-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Slippery Cider
notes: For cider - Medium body.  Medium to high acidity.  Not much noticeable tannin presence except that the flavor seems lightly nutty and spiced. Overall Impression - A good cider but not exceptional.  Interesting in subtle ways.  Could benefit from higher gravity or more tannins. Total tannins=0.15%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/slippery-cider-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Smokehouse
notes: For cider -Medium body and acidity.  The residual sweetness is more noticeable than it was for most of the ciders we tested (we won't speculate as to the reason since there are a number of possible explanations).  Not much noticeable tannin except for a hint of astringency on the finish. Overall Impression - Very drinkable.  Very good.  Well balanced on its own and great for a base.  Total tannins=0.15%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/smokehouse-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Swiss Limbertwig
notes: For cider - Medium body.  Medium to high acidity.  Mild bitterness and astringency fills out the cider. Overall Impression - Nice, balanced.  Good all around.  Total tannins=0.20%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/swiss-limbertwig-apple-cider-evaluation

name: Apple Juice - Stump
notes: For cider - Light to medium body.  Low to medium acidity.  Mild apple flavor.  Little to no noticeable tannins. Overall Impression - Unremarkable, but not bad.  Total tannins=0.10%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/stump

name: Apple Juice - Tremlett's Bitter
notes: Intense, well known English cider apple very high in tannins.  For cider -Unfortunately we did not have enough juice from Tremlett's Bitter to create a single varietal cider for further testing. Total tannins=1.20%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/tremletts-bitter

name: Apple Juice - Wolf River
notes: From the banks of the Wolf River in Wisconsin. For cider - Low to medium body.  Classic tart apple flavor.  Little to no noticeable tannins.  Overall Impression - Good base apple with a straight-forward tart apple flavor.  Would be enjoyable on a hot day when floating down the Wolf River. Total tannins=0.11%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/new-page

name: Apple Juice - Yarlington Mill
notes: Traditional English Cider apple.  For cider - Full body.  Rich.  Slight residual sweetness is noticeable with the low acidity.  Pleasant tannins - lightly drying and slight bitterness.  Notes of oak, spiced rum, molasses, anise. Overall Impression - Wow!  Definitely a stand out cider apple.  Wish more ciders tasted like that. Total tannins=0.20%. For more info see - https://brixcider.com/yarlington-mill

notes: Pressed grape juice for wine making.  Sugar level at 19 brix.  Edit the details->name of the ingredient to specify grape variety or blend

name: Admiral Pils
notes: PRODUCES A BRIGHT STRAW WORT WITH NOTES OF HONEYSUCKLE, VANILLA AND DRY GRASS. Our take on the classic style, Admiral Pils is made from low protein barley that is lightly kilned to produce a malt with delicate color and clean, vibrant flavor. Admiral Pils is a great choice to deliver freshly kilned malt aroma to old world lagers, saisons and farmhouse ales, and any other lightly-colored styles.

name: Admiral's Hearth
notes: Dark Munich-style malt CONTRIBUTES A WARM, AMBER COLOR AND RICH, MALTY SWEETNESS WITH AROMAS OF BREAD CRUST, TOFFEE AND CAKE

name: California Spirit Distillers Malt
notes: HIGH DP, ENZYMATIC MALT FOR DISTILLING California Spirit is our malt for grain distilling. Its higher protein content and malting process deliver robust alpha amylase content and the high diastatic power distillers require when working with unmalted grains. The low kilning temperature gives California Spirit a green malt, freshly mown grass flavor profile

name: Clipper Oats
notes: AROMAS OF OATS AND CAKE WITH HINTS OF CHOCOLATE, HAY, PECAN, CLOVER AND HONEYSUCKLE Clipper Oats are malted and kilned with their husk intact, giving them good lautering properties even when used at relatively high percentages. They add a nice, toasty oat flavor along with the grain’s signature body and mouthfeel.

name: Feldblume
notes: A LIGHT GOLDEN MALT WITH FLORAL AROMAS OF CLOVER AND HAY AND A MILD SCONE-LIKE SWEETNESS

name: Gallagher's Best
notes: A WELL BALANCED PALE ALE MALT. BRIGHT AROMA OF MULTIGRAIN CRACKERS AND HAY. MILDLY SWEET FLAVOR OF TOAST WITH HONEY.

name: Kilnsmith I
notes: IMPARTS A LIGHT BROWN COLOR WITH EARTHY AND SWEET AROMAS OF PRETZEL, DRIED FRUIT AND HONEY Our one of a kind kiln produces caramel malts that undergo a combination of caramelization and complex Maillard reactions to produce deep color and robust aroma and flavor with more fermentable extract and less residual sweetness than caramel and crystal malts of comparable color produced in drum roasters.

name: Kilnsmith III
notes: IMPARTS A RICH, RUBY BROWN COLOR WITH NOTES OF GRAPE NUTS, TOFFEE AND BROWN SUGAR Our one of a kind kiln produces caramel malts that undergo a combination of caramelization and complex Maillard reactions to produce deep color and robust aroma and flavor with more fermentable extract and less residual sweetness than caramel and crystal malts of comparable color produced in drum roasters.

name: Maiden Voyage
notes: BISCUITY PALE MALT WITH EARTHY AND SWEET AROMAS OF DRY GRASS AND TOAST WITH HONEY AND PEANUT BUTTER

name: Midway
notes: Munich-style malt CONTRIBUTES RICH AMBER COLOR WITH FRUITY SWEETNESS AND AROMAS OF CINNAMON, BREAD CRUST, GRAHAM CRACKER, TOAST AND PRETZEL

name: Pacific Victor
notes: Vienna-style malt CONTRIBUTES A LIGHT ORANGE HUE AND NOTES OF SWEET TEA, BREAKFAST CEREAL, HONEY, AND ALMOND

name: Yolo Gold Wheat
notes: PROVIDES A ROUND, PILLOWY MOUTHFEEL WHILE CONTRIBUTING NOTES OF HAY, MINERAL, AND FRESHLY RISING DOUGH Yolo Gold is our ode to the pale golden hills of the Sacramento Valley, where our hard white Patwin wheat is grown. Through restrained modification on the malting floor, this malt retains attributes of raw wheat while adding kilned characteristics similar to our Admiral Pils. Use up to 50% for traditional wheat-forward styles, or in smaller amounts to contribute a pillowy mouthfeel and round body to just about any beer style, from Hefeweizen to hazy IPA.

name: Munich Malt, Germany (Avangard)
notes: A malt with enough diastatic power to convert itself but often used in conjunction with other base malts to contribute maltiness and an orange color.

name: Pilsner Malt (Avangard)
notes: Highly-modified, it has been reported that brewers tend to get excellent efficiency out of this malt. It produces beers with a nice light golden color. Avangard pilsner malt can be used in a range of different styles and in any beer that calls for pilsner malt.

name: Vienna Malt (Avangard)
notes: Darker than pale malt, Vienna malt is a great base malt that contributes golden colors and biscuity, malty flavors.

name: Wheat Malt (Avangard)
notes: It can be used as the base in any wheat beer, from traditional German Hefeweizens to American and Belgian wheat beers. In addition, it can be used in small amounts in other styles to increase body and head retention.

name: Amber Malt (Bairds)
notes: Amber malt has a light, biscuity, dry flavour and can be used to produce some Bitter and Mild Ales and sweet Stouts in the UK, as well as the traditional London Porters that have come back into favour recently. The flavour is quite intense and caution in the use of this material is required.

name: Black Malt (Bairds)
notes: Black Malt, sometimes loosely described as Roasted Malt, is used in the production of very dark beers. The flavor, as might be expected, is a more intense version of Chocolate malt and, because of its colour and flavor, needs to be used with care.

name: Caramalt Malt - 15L (Bairds)
notes: Crystal or Caramel malts have a distinctive toffee flavour, which becomes more intense as colour is increased, and at the higher end of the colour range burnt or roasted malt flavours may begin to appear. Traditionally in the UK, Crystal malt of colour 70-80 °ASBC has been used at about 5% of the grist to give the characteristic colour and flavour of UK Bitters and Pale Ales.

name: Caramalt Malt - 35L (Bairds)
notes: Crystal or Caramel malts have a distinctive toffee flavour, which becomes more intense as colour is increased, and at the higher end of the colour range burnt or roasted malt flavours may begin to appear. Traditionally in the UK, Crystal malt of colour 70-80 °ASBC has been used at about 5% of the grist to give the characteristic colour and flavour of UK Bitters and Pale Ales.

name: Caramalt Malt - 55L (Bairds)
notes: Crystal or Caramel malts have a distinctive toffee flavour, which becomes more intense as colour is increased, and at the higher end of the colour range burnt or roasted malt flavours may begin to appear. Traditionally in the UK, Crystal malt of colour 70-80 °ASBC has been used at about 5% of the grist to give the characteristic colour and flavour of UK Bitters and Pale Ales.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 110L (Bairds)
notes: Crystal or Caramel malts have a distinctive toffee flavour, which becomes more intense as colour is increased, and at the higher end of the colour range burnt or roasted malt flavours may begin to appear. Traditionally in the UK, Crystal malt of colour 70-80 °ASBC has been used at about 5% of the grist to give the characteristic colour and flavour of UK Bitters and Pale Ales.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 150L (Bairds)
notes: Crystal or Caramel malts have a distinctive toffee flavour, which becomes more intense as colour is increased, and at the higher end of the colour range burnt or roasted malt flavours may begin to appear. Traditionally in the UK, Crystal malt of colour 70-80 °ASBC has been used at about 5% of the grist to give the characteristic colour and flavour of UK Bitters and Pale Ales.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 65L (Bairds)
notes: Crystal or Caramel malts have a distinctive toffee flavour, which becomes more intense as colour is increased, and at the higher end of the colour range burnt or roasted malt flavours may begin to appear. Traditionally in the UK, Crystal malt of colour 70-80 °ASBC has been used at about 5% of the grist to give the characteristic colour and flavour of UK Bitters and Pale Ales.

name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 75 (Bairds)
notes: Crystal or Caramel malts have a distinctive toffee flavour, which becomes more intense as colour is increased, and at the higher end of the colour range burnt or roasted malt flavours may begin to appear. Traditionally in the UK, Crystal malt of colour 70-80 °ASBC has been used at about 5% of the grist to give the characteristic colour and flavour of UK Bitters and Pale Ales.

name: Chocolate Malt (Bairds)
notes: Chocolate malt is used in the production of Porters and sweet Stouts. Chocolate malt has a rich chocolate and coffee flavour and aroma with a light astringency. A great deal of care is needed in the use of this material because of its intense colour and flavour. Manufacture is similar to Amber malt but higher final temperatures are used. Flavour again is due to pyrazines and pyrroles.

name: Munich Malt (Bairds)
notes: Munich malt is used in the production of dark Dunkel Lagers, which are dark in colour with a brownish tinge. Munich malt is only a part of the grist, along with pale Lager malt and perhaps Caramalt. The malt is a well-modified Lager malt, which is kilned in such a way that modification continues during kilning and very high finishing heats are used to produce the characteristic colour and flavour.

name: Pale Ale Malt (Bairds)
notes: Pale Ale malt forms the majority of the grist for a typical UK Pale Ale or Bitter beer and is made from some of the best spring and winter barley available. There is an emphasis on low protein barley to provide higher extract levels but still acceptable levels of enzymes. The barley will be fully-steeped and germinated before the green malt is loaded to the kiln. Kilning is a carefully controlled process removing moisture to a relatively low level without destroying excessive amounts of enzymes but imparting characteristic flavour and colour. Even with a diastase of only 45 IOB there is still enough activity to convert for example 5% of Crystal malt and 5 -10% of cooked adjunct (e.g. flaked maize).

name: Pilsner/Lager Malt (Bairds)
notes: Pilsen / Lager Malt is used for brewing all malt Premium Lagers. There is an emphasis on low protein and the relatively low soluble nitrogen ratio. This ensures good extract levels, no haze problems and low Dimethylsulfide (DMS) potential. Steeping and germination are carefully controlled to prevent excessive modification and to preserve head retention values in the beer. Kilning of the green malt is carefully programmed to prevent excessive colour formation yet sufficient heat is applied to ensure that DMS potential is limited. Although mainly intended for all malt beers, there is sufficient diastatic power to convert a limited amount of adjunct. Care has to be taken that not too much adjunct is used or flavour could be impaired. Also, excessive dilution of soluble nitrogen could result in yeast nutrition problems, causing poor fermentation or flavour defects due to diacetyl, for example

name: Roasted Barley (Bairds)
notes: Roast Barley. This product is used in the production of dry or bitter Stouts and other dark beers, or for the careful adjustment of Pilsen beer colours. A different, slower roasting temperature profile is used but the final temperature is 220°C or even higher, which is achieved by allowing the exothermic roasting reactions to continue after turning off the heat source. The reaction is stopped by quenching with water. Because of the high temperature at the end, colour pick-up at this stage is very rapid and extreme care is needed to prevent carbonisation.

name: Vienna Malt (Bairds)
notes: Vienna Malt is used for making dark lager beer of the Vienna or Märzen style, dark in colour with a reddish tinge. Vienna malt usually only forms around 10 -15% of the grist with normal Lager malt and perhaps Caramalt. The malt is a well-modified Lager malt, resulting from full steeping and germination. The colour is achieved by kilning at higher temperatures than usual for Lager malts. Because it only forms a part of the grist, diastatic activity is less important.

name: Pale Malt (Barrett Burston)
notes: Pale malt suitable as a base malt for most beer styles.

name: Pale Malt, Ale (Barrett Burston)
notes: Good pale 2-row base spring malting grade barley. Well-modified and kilned malt is required.

name: Pale Malt, Galaxy (Barrett Burston)
notes: Highly modified pale malt suitable as a base for many light to medium body beer styles.  Use for most ales and lagers.

name: Wheat Malt (Barrett Burston)
notes: Wheat base malt suitable for all wheat styles.

name: BEST Acidulated (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST  Acidulated Malt  reduces  the  pH of  the  mash. This  results  in improved  enzyme  activity  of  the mash, greater yield and flavor stability as well as a  lighter  color and  a  balanced  aroma  in  the  finished  beer.  It  also represents an  interesting  alternative  for  breweries  that  have  no  mash  acidification.

name: BEST Caramel Aromatic (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Caramel Aromatic will impart a distinct, almost exaggerated  malt  aroma  and  flavor  to red lagers, amber lagers, dark lagers, German bocks and other beer styles, even at a rate as los as 10 %. As with all BEST caramel malts, this malt is of exceptional quality, both due to its excellent processing characteristics and superior flavor.

name: BEST Black Malt eXtra (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST  Black  Malt eXtra (roasted  malt)  gives  the  beer extremely deep colors and intensive roasted bread, dark chocolate or coffee notes. The malt flavor is also emphasized. Similar to the somewhat ligther BEST Black Malt, the eXtra version is also produced from green or kiln-dried malt which is roasted using a smooth and gentle technology. While roasting can result in undesirable pyrazine tastes, our BESTMALZ roasting technology applies the heat in a statd of the art fashion. This malt is as black as great malt can be. It will enrich your brew with a wild spectrum of tastes.

name: BEST Black Malt (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST  Black  Malt  (roasted  malt)  gives  the  beer greater depth of color and adds more intensive nuances of chocolate  or  coffee  aromas.  The  malt  flavour  is also  emphasised. The  foam  characteristics  are not affected. The  malt  is  produced  from  green  or  kiln-dried malt which is roasted using a smooth and gentle technology. While roasting can result in undesirable pyrazine tastes. Our BESTMALZ roasting technology applies the heat in a state-of-the-art fashion. Evenly roasted malt kernels with optimal processing features are the outcomes of this advanced technique fine tuned by our experienced malt masters.

name: BEST Caramel Amber (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Caramel  Amber reinforces the typical `caramely´ malt aroma of the beer. It gives the beer a darker color  and  increases  foam stability.  In  addition,  it  enhances  the  full-bodied  character of the beer. After  the  germination  is  finished,  the  green  malt  is gently roasted using a special process. This produces the unique BESTMALZ caramel aroma.

name: BEST Caramel Hell (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Caramel Hell reinforces the typical “caramely” malt aroma of the beer. It gives the beer a darker  color  and  increases  foam  stability.  In  addition,  it  enhances  the  full-bodied  creamy character  of  the  beer. After the germination is finished, the green malt is gently  roasted  using  a  special  process. This creates the special caramel aroma. This malt is produced by our specifially developed germination and roasting technique. The malt has a unique with an elegant touch of sweatness. It has excellent processing characteristics. This malt has rich and superior flavors.

name: BEST Caramel Pils (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Caramel  Pils  optimizes  the  foam  properties and sweet full-bodied character of the beer. The malt character resembles that of BEST Pilsner malt. After the germination is finished, the green malt is gently roasted and optimized over many years by our BESTMALZ malt masters. This process is responsible for our unique BESTMALZ Caramel aromas. As all our BEST caramel malts, this malt impresses with excellent processing characteristics and with a superior flavor.

name: BEST Melanoidin (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Melanoidin contains  a  particularly large amount of dextrins. It gives the beer a strong flavor and a reddish color. The full-bodied nature of the beer is enhanced. It is produced according to a speial kilning process. Without any problems can it be used in percentages of up to 50 % despite its strongly coloring impact.

name: BEST Munich (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Munich intensifies  the  color of  the  beer. It emphasises the malt aroma of dark beer in an exciting way. It forms an excellent enzyme-rich foundation for all color-intensive beer styles. This malt is produced using a special malting process designed to bring out certain desirable qualities, such as high solubility.

name: BEST Munich Dark (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Munich Dark gives a pleasant full-bodied and malty flavor. The impact when using this darker malt is similar to BEST Munich: the color is even more intensified, the malt aroma ist strengthened. Enzyme richness of this malt offers opportunities for brewing strongly colored beers. The production process for this malt is similar to the lighter variant of our BEST Munich.

name: BEST Pale Ale (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Pale Ale deepens the light “golden” color of top-fermented beers, creating a pleasant flavor. It forms an excellent enzyme-rich foundation for intensive colored beer styles. It  is  an  excellent  base  malt  for  brewing  many  different styles of British Pale Ale as well as for brewing Kölsch beer.

name: BEST Pilsen Malt (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Pilsen Malt  gives  beer  a  fresh  and  rounded taste.  It is used for all types of beers based on basically berley malt.  It  forms  an excellent “light” and enzyme-rich  foundation  for  almost  all  beer styles. Malt characteristics: low protein levels, high extract content, light color and high enzymatic activity. BEST Pilsen Malt is also available in organic quality.

name: BEST Red X (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Red X has been invented for brewing red-tinted beers. You can use BEST Red X for up to 100% of your grain bill –  no other  malt  is  required.  Offering exceptional reliability and optimal processability, BEST Red  X  can  be  employed  to  brew  consistently  fiery beers  with  intense  reddish  hues. Its full-bodied  flavor and  attractive,  unique  color  coupled  with  easy  handling in the brewery make BEST Red X the best choice for creating a broad range of new beers, such as red-tinted wheat beers.

name: BEST Smoked (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Smoked  gives  beer  a  typical  smoky  flavor similar to that in smoked ham. The quantity used will influence the intensity of the beech wood or whisky flavor. This  malt  can not only be used for beer but also for distillate production.  It  has high enzymatic activity.

name: BEST Vienna (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Vienna deepens  the  light  and  brilliant  color of the beer and creates a pleasant, full-bodied and malty taste. Selected malting barley is used to produce the malt and it is created according to a special malting process. This malt has a high enzymatic potential.

name: BEST Wheat Malt (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Wheat  Malt  emphasises  the  effervescent freshness  and  the  typical  top-fermented  flavor  of wheat beer. It is produced  from  high  quality  brewing  wheat. Malting processes adapted to the raw material highlight the particular qualities of this malt.

name: BEST Wheat Malt Dark (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST  Wheat  Malt  Dark  emphasises  the  effervescent freshness  and  the  typical  top-fermented  flavor of wheat beer. Very much like our brighter version of BEST Wheat Malt does. This malt, however, adds color and intensifies the aroma. It is produced  from  high  quality  brewing  wheat.  Malting  processes  adapted  to  the raw material highlight the particular qualities of this malt.

name: BEST Special X (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Special X imparts to beer- depending on the amount in the grist - a smooth raosty flavor reminiscent of raisins or dried fruit. The beer posesses a chestnut to dark hue (depending on rate) and an aromatic and harmonious full- bodied character. The malt does not, however, introduce bitter roasted flavors but rather brings a mild smoothness to beer without any of the astingent qualities associated with other dark malts. BEST Special X is a cool and crafty malt - product. Any craft - brewer should try- out this malt in his or her creations and impress with a rich mix of flavors.

name: BEST Caramel Munich I (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Caramel Munich I brings out the full spectrum of caramel taste that nature has put in the kernel. Like our other caramels, this malt will darken your beer and stabilize its foam. Depending on grain bill composition nuts and almonds may be reflected. Like all our BESTMALZ caramels, BEST Caramel Munich I to III are produced by using a unique germination and roasting technuque. Our malt masters have developed this gentle but yet effective process in order to generate caramel tastes of different variations and degrees. As a result, all BEST Caramels have great processing features and are highly comfortable in their use.

name: BEST Heidelberg (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Heidelberg is used especially for brewing beers extremely light in color. It forms an excellent `light´ and enzymerich foundation for almost all beer styles. Malt characteristics: low protein levels, high extract content, very light color and high enzymatic activity.

name: BEST Melanoidin Light (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Melanoidin Light contains an appreciable amont of dextrines and Maillard products, which emphasize the rich taste and flavor stability of the beer. It gives the beer a fuller flavor and a sligtly reddish color. The fullbodied nature of the beer is enhanced. It is produced according to a special kilning process.

name: BEST Chocolate (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Chocolate gives the beer an even darker color- like dark chocolate. It adds fine nuances of chocolate, nut, or coffee aromas. Dosages up to 10 % are possible without any bitter pryazine flavor. The color of the foam will not be affected but foam stability will be improved. The malt is produced from green or kiln-dried malt in a gentle roasting process.

name: BEST Heidelberg Wheat Malt (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Heidelberg Wheat Malt emphasizes the effervescent freshness and the typical top-fermented flavor of wheat beer. If can be used for light-colored beers. It is produced from high quality brewing wheat. Malting processes adapted to the raw material highlight the particular qualities of this malt.

name: BEST Caramel Munich II (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Caramel Munich II ist our mid range Munich caramel: very `caramely´ , adding deep color, increasing foam stability. In addition, it enhances the fullbodied character of the beer with intensive nut flavors. BEST Caramel Munich I to III are produced by using a unique germination and roasting technique. Our malt maters have developed this gentle but yet effective process in order to generate caramel tastes of different variations and degrees. All our BEST Caramels have unique processing feartures and are highly comfortable in their use.

name: BEST Chit Malt (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Chit Malt is used for balancing the characteristics of strongly solubilized malt. When using this malt, foam formation is promoted and foam stability increases. The malt is produced from the same two-row spring barley as is used for all other BESTMALZ malt types.

name: BEST Peated (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Peated is smoked over a peat fire using the best avaiable peat. The smoke imparts a strong smoky, phenolic flavor which is reflected in the malt aroma. Brewers can use up to 100 % in the grain bill. Depending on the composition and intensity in the grain bill this malt will generate flavors from light to intense peat and earthy tastes. Great not only for beers but also for distullates. (Phenols 5-50 ppm)

name: BEST Caramel Munich III (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Caramel Munich III (crystal malt) intensifies the beer color and malty aroma of dark caramels and dried fruits. It gives the beer a significantly darker color and increases foam stability. In addition, it enhances the full-bodied character of the beer with flavor of intensive roasted almond. BEST Caramel Munich I to III are produced by using a unique germination and roasting technique. Our malt maters have developed this gentle but yet effective process in order to generate caramel tastes of different variations and degrees.  Brew master love this dark malt for its unique features.

name: BEST Roasted Barley (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Roasted Barley imparts a characteristic deep dark color to beer. Depending on the amount used in the grain bill, the flavor profile can exhibit intense roasty notes and bitterness reminiscent of black coffee or Italian espresso. The foam stability of the beer is also improved.

name: BEST Spelt Malt (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Spelt Malt is used for producing full-bodied, top-fermented beers. Spelt is an ancient grain and is know to possess a number of healt beneifits. For this reason, spelt was the favorite grain of the medieval pioneers of today´s health movement. German nun, Hildegrad von Bingen, born in the year 1098 is famous for using spelt in her recipes. Likewise, spelt beer, is considerd highly digestible and conductive to good health. This malt improves foam stability. It can also have other positive effects in the brewing process.

name: BEST Rye Malt (BESTMALZ)
notes: BEST Rye Malt imparts an incomparable structure, a velvetly smooth mouthfeel and an extraordinary complexity. The aroma intensely reminds of bread crumbs. Due to missing husks and the high amount of mucilage (pentosanes) more than 60 % of BEST Rye Malt in the grain bill is not recommended, as it leads to serious lauteing problems.

name: Candi Syrup, D-180
notes: Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. It has the unmistakable flavors of fresh ground coffee, dark stone fruit, and hint of dark toasted bread with some notes of anise and dark chocolate. D-180 is the basis for many dark Belgian Ales.

name: Candi Syrup, D-45
notes: Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  A rich translucent amber syrup. The unmistakable toffee, vanilla, caramel, and lightly toasted flavors. Exceedingly good in Brown Ales or medium Golden Ale's that require an aromatic nose and subtle flavor.

name: Candi Syrup, D-90
notes: Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  The most versatile of our Belgian style Candi Syrups and is made with pure Beet sugar. This syrup creates an unmistakable and subtle mild palate of dark chocolate, dark stone fruit, slight hint of coffee, toffee, and medium-toasted bread notes. This syrup will insure the caramel aroma and rich flavors of award winning Belgian style ales.

name: Candi Syrup, Golden
notes: Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  A decadent Golden Belgian style Candi Syrup that contributes rich caramel flavors followed by a subtle fruit back-palate. Good in Belgian Golden Ale's, Tripels, Bier de Garde, Saison, Belgian Blonde, and all lighter Belgian Ale's.

name: Candi Syrup, Simplicity
notes: Candi Syrup used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales.  A good balance of highly fermentable sugars with a faint "citrusy" flavor and/or mild honey palate. A unique blonde Belgian style Candi Syrup. Good for Saisons, Triples, and Golden Ale's. It is readily fermentable and creates a refreshing subtle flavor.

name: Soft Candi Sugar, Blanc (White)

name: Soft Candi Sugar, Brun Foncé (Dark)
notes: Dark Brown Soft Candi Sugar. The darkest and most flavorful cassonade on the market. It contributes notable dark fruit and subtle caramel flavors at the same time. Ideal for all darker ales.

name: Soft Candi Sugar, Brun Léger (Light)
notes: Light Brown Soft Candi Sugar. A slightly lighter premium Soft Candi Sugar with delicate and smooth toasted caramel overtones. Ideal for Dubbels and Belgian Pale's.

name: CHÂTEAU ABBEY NATURE®
notes: Features: Belgian brown malt. Specially germinated and kilned at up to 110°C. Characteristics: Château Abbey® malt is a more toasted form of pale malt. Gives a strong taste of cooked bread, nuts and fruit. Château Abbey® malt has a bitter flavour which mellows on ageing, and can be quite intensely flavoured. Château Abbey® malt is typically used as a small proportion of the grist in the production of beers requiring some substantial depth of colour. Usage: Pale ale beers, Abbey beers, brown porter and special beers, in a diverse range of British beers. Up to 10% of the mix. 45EBC (European Beer Convention) 17.4°L (Lovibond) Moisture % 4.5 Extract (dry basis) % 78.0 Wortcolour EBC (°L) 41.0 (15.9) 49.0 (18.9) pH 5.8

name: CHÂTEAU ACID
notes: Features: It is an acidulated with lactobacilli barley malt which lowers the mash pH and is used when brewing with bicarbonate-rich water. Characteristics: Château Acid malt improves the performance of the hydrolytic enzymes and provides a better mash working. It also intensifies the fermentation by adjusting the pH level. Acid malt enhances a well-rounded taste in your beer and gives stability to its head. name: CHÂTEAU BISCUIT NATURE®
notes: Features: Unique and very special Belgian malt. Lightly kilned, then lightly torrefied at up to 160°C. Characteristics: Château Biscuit® malt produces a very pronounced "toasty" finish in the beer. Imparts a warm bread and biscuit-like aroma and flavour. Promotes a light to medium warm brown colour of the mash. This malt is used to improve the roasted flavour and aroma that characterize ales and lagers lending the subtle properties of black and chocolate malts. No enzymes. Must be mashed with malts having a surplus of diastatic power. Usage: All special beers and as well for English ales, brown ales and porters. name: CHÂTEAU BUCKWHEAT
notes: Features: Malted from buckwheat, a pseudo-cereal*, Château Buckwheat malt is used to produce gluten-free beer. Château Buckwheat malt may contain traces of other malt grains containing gluten. *Pseudocereals are broadleaf plants (non-grasses) that are used in much the same way as cereals (true cereals are grasses). Their seed can be ground into flour and otherwise used as cereals. Examples of pseudocereals are amaranth, quinoa, and buckwheat. Characteristics: Château Buckwheat malt is used in the production of gluten-free beer. Adds a particular nutty and malty flavor to your beer. It also can be used in specialty beers to render a rich and deep tone. NB! Buckwheat malt has no diastatic power. Usage: Any type of gluten-free beer; 50 –100 % of the mix. 4 –15 EBC (European Brewing Convention) 2.1 –6.2°L (Lovibond) Moisture % 8.0 Extract (dry basis) % 65.3 Wortcolour EBC (°L) 4.0 (2.1)-15.0 (6.2) Total Protein (dry malt) % - 11.0

name: CHÂTEAU CHOCOLAT
notes: Features: Belgian chocolate malt. Torrefied at 220°C and then quickly cooled when the desired colour is reached. Characteristics: Château Chocolat malt is a highly roasted malt with a deep brown colour. This is where its name comes from. Château Chocolat malt is used to adjust the colour of beer and imparts a nutty, toasted flavour. Château Chocolat malt shares many of the characteristics of Black Malt but provides a less bitter flavour than Black malt and is lighter than Black, because it is roasted for a slightly shorter period of time and the end temperatures are not so high. Usage: Brown, strong, darker and black beers, such as porters, stouts and brown ales. Up to 7% of the mix. 900 EBC (European Brewing Convention) 338.1°L (Lovibond) Moisture % 4.5 Extract (dry basis) % 75.0 Wortcolour EBC (°L) 800.0 (300.6) 1000.0 (375.6)

name: CHÂTEAU DISTILLING
notes: Features: Two row spring malting barley is selected for the production of our Château Distilling malt. Barley is steeped to 44 - 46% moisture, slightly higher than normally required for Pilsen lager style malts. Germination temperatures are controlled between 12°C - 16°C for a period of five days. Kiln cycles start at 50° - 60°C rising to 70° - 75°C. Characteristics: This is a premium Distilling malt produced especially for the distilling industry. It is used for the production of quality grain whisky. Château Distilling malt promotes high fermentability, adequate enzyme potential and soluble nitrogen (protein) levels. Our Château Distilling malt is gently kilned to preserve enzymes and maximise fermentability. Usage: Any type of whisky, real Scotch whisky. name: CHÂTEAU MUNICH
notes: 25 EBC (European Brewing Convention) Features: Belgian specialty malt of Münich type. Kilned up to 100-105°C. Characteristics: Rich, golden malt. Provides a modest colour increase toward a nice, golden-orange colour. Adds a pronounced grainy malty flavour to many beer styles without affecting the foam stability and body. Is also used in small quantities in combination with Château Pilsen 2RS to produce light colour beers, improving the malty flavour and giving the beer a richer colour. Enhances the taste of character beers. Usage: Pale ale, amber, brown, strong and dark beers, bocks %: Up to 60% of the mix Moisture % 4.5 Extract (dry basis) % 80.0 Wort colour EBC (°L) 21.0 (8.4) 28.0 (11.1) Total Protein (dry malt) % 11.5 Clarity of wort % clear

name: CHÂTEAU OAT
notes: Features: Château Oat malt is produced from de-husked oat kernels. This type of malt has a very low diastatic power and moderate extract values. Characteristics: Château Oat malt gives a distinctive silkiness to the beer. Great for enhancing body, head retention, and flavor of dark beers. Used as a flavor adjunct, it enhances a biscuit taste in the beer and gives it a unique texture and a creamy mouthfeel. Adds texture and flavor to any dark English beer style. Usage: Dark beers, porters, stouts, robust British ales, winter beers. 2.3 EBC (European Brewing Convention) 1.4°L (Lovibond) Moisture % 7.0 Extract (dry basis) % 59.5 Wortcolour EBC (°L) 2.3 (1.4) Total Protein (dry malt) % 11.0

name: CHÂTEAU PALE ALE
notes: Features: Belgian light-coloured base malt. Kilning at up to 90-95°C. Characteristics: Usually used as a base malt or in combination with Pilsen 2RS malt to impart a richer malt flavour and additional colour. Being deeper in colour, this malt can add a golden hue to the wort. It is used with strong yeasts to produce amber and bitter beers. Château Pale Ale malt is kilned longer and is usually better modified, providing a more pronounced flavour than Pilsen 2RS. The enzymatic activity of Château Pale Ale malt is sufficient when used with large proportion of non-enzymatic specialty malts. Usage: Pale ale styles and bitter beers, most traditional English beer styles. 7 – 10 EBC (European Brewing Convention) 3.2 – 4.3°L (Lovibond) %: Up to 100% of the mix Moisture % 4.5 Extract (dry basis) % 81.0 Difference fine – coarse % 1.0-2.5 Wort colour EBC (°L) 7.0 (3.2) 10.0 (4.3) Total Protein (dry malt) % 11.5 Soluble protein % 4.0 4.6 Kolbach Index % 38.0 45.0 Viscosity cp 1.60 Diastatic power WK 250 Friability % 80.0 NDMA ppb 2.5

name: CHÂTEAU ROASTED BARLEY
notes: Features: Raw roasted barley. Torrefied up to 230 ºC. The length of roasting time determines the darkness of the grain. Characteristics: Château Roasted Barley is a highly roasted barley that imparts a burnt, grainy, coffee-like flavor to your beer. It has many characteristics of Château Black malt, though it is far more complex. It actually has some starch that can be converted during the mash, thus impacting the specific gravity. Château Roasted Barley will also lend to the sweetness to the beer. If compared to Château Chocolat and Château Black malts, roasted barley produces the lightest colored head. Imparts a deep red mahogany color to beer and very strong roasted flavor. Gives dryness to Porters and Stouts. Usage: Stouts, Porters, Nut Brown Ales and other dark beer styles. 2-4% in Brown ales, or 3-10% in Porters and Stouts. 1200 EBC (European Brewing Convention) 450.6°L (Lovibond) Moisture % 4.5 Extract (dry basis) % 65.0 Wortcolour EBC (°L) 1000 (375.6) 1300 (488.1)

name: CHÂTEAU VIENNA
notes: Features: Belgian Vienna base malt. Lightly kilned at up to 85-90°C with shorter "cure" duration. Characteristics: Imparts a richer flavour of malt and grain than Pilsen malt and adds subtle aromas of caramel and toffee. Château Vienna malt is kilned at slightly higher temperatures than Pilsen Malt. As a result Château Vienna malt gives a deeper golden colour to the beer increasing at the same time its body and fullness. Due to the higher kilning temperature, the enzyme activity of Château Vienna malt is slightly lower than that of Pilsen Malt. Nevertheless, our Château Vienna malt has a sufficient enzymatic activity to be used in combination with large proportion of specialty malts. Usage: All beer styles, Vienna lager. To enhance colour and aroma of light beers. %: Up to 100% of the mix 4 – 7 EBC (European Brewing Convention) 2.1 – 3.2°L (Lovibond) Moisture % 4.5 Extract (dry basis) % 80.0 Difference fine – coarse % 1.5-2.5 Wort colour EBC (°L) 4.0 (2.1)- 7.0 (3.2) Total Protein (dry malt) % 11.5 Kolbach Index % 37.0- 45.0 Viscosity cp 1.65 Friability % 80.0 Glassiness % 2.5 Saccharification time min normal

name: CHÂTEAU WHEAT BLANC
notes: Features: Wheat malt. Kilned at up to 80 - 85°C. Characteristics: Enhances the peculiar taste of wheat beers. Château Wheat Blanc malt is essential in making wheat beers but is also used in barley malt-based beers (3–5%) thanks to its protein level that gives the beer a fuller mouthfeel and enhanced head stability. Usage: Wheat beers, white, light beers, beers with low or no alcohol. Usage: Any type of whisky for a distinct smoky flavour of real Scotch whisky. Up to 100% of the mix. name: Australian Pale Ale Extract (Coopers)

name: Dark Ale Extract (Coopers)

name: Draught Extract (Coopers)

name: English Bitter Extract (Coopers)
notes: A coppery-brown colour with hues of red, a creamy head, floral aroma and a blend of toasty-sweet malt flavours that’ll have you transported back to the early 1800s. By eck, it’s grand. Weight - 1.7kg, Colour - 420EBC, Bitterness - 590IBU, Aroma Hop - Styrian Golding

name: Heritage Lager Extract (Coopers)

name: Irish Stout Extract (Coopers)
notes: Rich and dark with coffee, chocolate and licorice aromas. To think of all that silky, smooth, malted, roasty-ness without licking your lips is impossible. Weight - 1.7kg, Colour - 1500EBC, Bitterness - 560IBU

name: Lager Extract (Coopers)
notes: A true blue Aussie lager with plenty of character. Light to medium palate with subtle malt and hop flavours. A clear finish and inviting golden-straw colour. Weight - 1.7kg, Colour - 90EBC, Bitterness - 390IBU

name: Mexican Cerveza Extract (Coopers)

name: Pilsener Extract (Coopers)
notes: Don’t let the pale, straw colour fool you. This classic pilsener has a bold, spicy Saaz hop aroma. It’s crisp and dry with a cleansing bitterness. Weight - 1.7kg, Colour - 70EBC, Bitterness - 420IBU, Aroma Hop - Saaz

name: Wheat Beer Extract (Coopers)

name: Chocolate (Crisp)

name: Heritage, Rye Malt (Double Eagle)

name: Legacy, Wheat Malt (Double Eagle)

name: Munich (Double Eagle)

name: Munich Xtra Malt (Double Eagle)

Delivers a darker amber color than traditional Munich plus some toffee flavors due to greater Maillard reactions during kilning. Adds a deep, slightly sweet malt character to any beer.Use to add color and moutheel to any beer style. 18-20 SRM

name: Organic Wheat (Gambrinus)
